docs.lead_paragraph: A bill that would return billions of dollars previously trimmed from Medicare payments to hospitals, nursing homes and other care providers was approved by the House today. The Medicare cash relief, $11.5 billion over five years, passed with broad bipartisan support by a vote of 388 to 25.

headline.main: House Approves a Bill for Medicare Relief

docs.abstract: House, in 388-25 vote, approves bill that would return billions of dollars previously trimmed from Medicare payments to hospitals, nursing homes and other care providers; bill will provide $11.5 billion over five years (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: In a dispute over reimbursement rates and terms, central New Jersey's largest regional hospital, Robert Wood Johnson University Hospital, has decided that it will no longer accept patients seeking elective treatment who are covered by Aetna U.S. Healthcare, the state's largest managed care company. The hospital's decision not to renew its contract with the insurer will go into effect between Dec. 1 and April 1. It will not apply to emergency patients, which the hospital is required by law to accept.

headline.main: Aetna H.M.O. Loses Contract With Hospital

docs.abstract: Robert Wood Johnson University Hospital, in dispute over reimbursement rates and terms, says it will no longer accept patients seeking elective treatment who are covered by Aetna US Healthcare, New Jersey's largest managed care company (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Bill Bradley, whose $65 billion health care plan has been attacked by Vice President Al Gore as ill conceived and too expensive, went on the offensive in East Harlem yesterday before some of the people most lacking in adequate health care. Speaking to more than 100 residents of East Harlem, a predominantly Puerto Rican community, Mr. Bradley, the former senator from New Jersey who is challenging Mr. Gore for the Democratic presidential nomination, reiterated his theme that the federal government should make health insurance affordable for almost all Americans.

headline.main: Bradley, in East Harlem, Pushes Health Care

docs.abstract: Democratic Presidential candidate Bill Bradley, speaking to over 100 East Harlem residents, reiterates his theme that federal government should make health insurance affordable for almost all Americans; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Bill Bradley, whose $65 billion health care plan has been attacked by Vice President Al Gore as ill conceived and too expensive, went on the offensive in East Harlem yesterday before some of the people most lacking in adequate health care.   ...

docs.lead_paragraph: House Speaker Dennis Hastert suffered an embarrassing defeat last month when 68 Republicans defied his leadership and voted with the Democrats to approve a strong patients' rights bill. Now he is trying to undo that vote through parliamentary maneuvers. The bipartisan patients' rights bill, sponsored by Charlie Norwood, Republican of Georgia, and John Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, seeks to set national standards for managed care companies and to give patients the right to sue health plans for damages caused by a denial of benefits. Republican leaders in the House have been fighting the liability provision and other strong patient protections for years, but this time around Mr. Hastert could not persuade enough members of his own party to vote no. It was the most striking rebuff to the leadership since the Republicans took control of the House in 1994.
docs.abstract: Editorial contends that House Speaker Dennis Hastert suffered embarrassing defeat when 68 Republicans defied his leadership and voted with Democrats to approve strong patients' rights bill; criticizes him for trying to undo that vote through parliamentary maneuvers

docs.lead_paragraph: Naomi Wolf, the feminist writer turned feminist campaign consultant, disputes the notion that she has been giving Al Gore secret lessons in how to bare his teeth, growl and get elected leader of the pack. In fact, Ms. Wolf calls the whole idea that she has been instructing him on how to be a dominant ''Alpha male'' rather than a subordinate ''Beta male'' a total fantasy.

headline.main: Naomi Wolf, Feminist Consultant to Gore, Clarifies Her Campaign Role

docs.lead_paragraph: A healthy economy and foul weather on Election Day allowed Republicans to retain their solid majority in New Jersey's 80 General Assembly races, leaders of both parties said today. Democrats picked up three seats over all on Tuesday, including the Fourth District seat in Camden and Gloucester counties, where the incumbent Republican, Gerald Luongo, had been dogged by allegations that he was involved in a questionable land deal. In Mercer County, Democrats captured the Hamilton Township mayor's office, which had been held by a Republican for 24 years. A strong Democratic turnout also helped topple two Republicans who held Assembly seats in the 14th District.
docs.abstract: Article on Republicans retaining their solid majority in New Jersey's 80 General Assembly races; Democrats picked up three seats over all (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Here is how the textbooks say a bill becomes law: The Senate passes the bill. Then the House of Representatives passes its own version. Then a conference committee is formed, where senior senators defend their bill and senior representatives defend their bill, with both sides striking compromises to resolve the differences. But in the real world of power politics, conventional procedures are sometimes flouted. That is what happened in the House today on legislation expanding the rights of patients in managed health-care plans. It threatens to undo the chamber's action on the bill.

headline.main: Congressional Memo; Not Quite Business as Usual In House on Managed Care

docs.abstract: Congressional Republican leaders, opposed to recent House passage of bill expanding rights of patients in managed-care health plans, are resorting to legislative tactic that threatens to undo chamber's action; are using their authority to make sure that Republican conferees named to negotiate with Senate are on their side; tactic could effectively stifle any action regulating managed care in current Congress (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: PacifiCare Health Systems Inc., the No. 1 operator of Medicare health maintenance organizations, is being sued by its members, who accuse it of using false advertising and unfair business practices. PacifiCare is accused of violating the California Consumer Legal Remedies Act by failing to disclose company policies that seek to keep down treatment costs and encourage physicians to avoid referring members to specialists, according to the suit filed on Tuesday in San Francisco County Superior Court.

docs.lead_paragraph: Organized criminal groups have infiltrated Medicare and Medicaid, and are skimming hundreds of millions of dollars a year from the programs, federal investigators said today. In a report to Congress, the General Accounting Office said the criminal groups had formed or corrupted scores of ''medical entities'' -- clinics, physician groups, diagnostic laboratories and medical equipment suppliers -- for the purpose of bilking Medicare and Medicaid, the insurance programs for people who are elderly, disabled or poor.

headline.main: U.S. Cites Criminals' Raids On Medicare and Medicaid

docs.abstract: Report to Congress by General Accounting office says organized criminal groups have infiltrated Medicare and Medicaid and are skimming hundreds of millions of dollars annually from programs; says criminal groups have formed or corrupted scores of 'medical entities'--such as clinics, physician groups, diagnostic laboratories and medical equipment suppliers--for purpose of bilking Medicare and Medicaid (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Democrats picked up three seats in elections for New Jersey's 80 State Assembly districts today, narrowing the Republicans' majority in the lower house of the Legislature to 45-to-35. In an off-year election that set records for high campaign spending and low voter turnout, Democratic challengers picked up at least one of the two seats in the 4th District in Camden and Gloucester Counties. Republican incumbent Gerald J. Luongo, who has faced criticism over involvement in a questionable land deal, appeared headed to defeat. His running mate, the incumbent George F. Geist, won re-election.

headline.main: Democrats Win Seats in Three Districts, Narrowing Republicans' Majority
